CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 6-1;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in GPE .
CARDINAL . The applicant proposed CARDINAL technological improvements to the company in which he worked . They were not accepted .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant filed an action with ORG . He claimed the protection of his intellectual property in that his above proposals were not accepted .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant amended his action in that he claimed that CARDINAL of the technological improvements proposed by him was submitted prior to other proposals concerning the same issue submitted by other persons , and that he should be compensated for both improvements proposed by him .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s action after having ordered CARDINAL expert opinions . On DATE the ORG quashed this decision on the ground that the first instance court had failed to establish the facts correctly and that it had proceeded erroneously .
CARDINAL . On DATE and on DATE the appellate court dismissed the applicant ’s requests for the exclusion of the ORG judges .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG appointed an expert . On DATE the expert informed ORG that he had a heavy workload and that he would be able to submit the opinion only after CARDINAL DATE . Subsequently ORG repeatedly urged the expert to submit the opinion . The opinion was submitted on DATE . On DATE the applicant submitted his comments on the opinion . On DATE he challenged the ORG judge . The ORG branch office of ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request for exclusion of ORG judge on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the case was adjourned as the defendant and the expert did not appear . The expert subsequently died .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG appointed an expert . The latter submitted the opinion on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG delivered an interim judgment in which it found , with reference to CARDINAL expert opinions , that the applicant ’s proposal concerning the circulation of air in the defendant company was to be given priority . ORG further dismissed the claim for compensation concerning the applicant ’s second proposal .

CARDINAL . The defendant appealed on DATE , and on CARDINAL DATE the ORG branch office of ORG quashed the first instance judgment to the extent that it had allowed the applicant ’s claim for his proposal to be given priority . The decision stated that the first instance court had failed to follow the instructions set out in ORG above decision of DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the experts with a view to clarifying the differences in their conclusions . On DATE it obtained a third expert ’s opinion . Hearings were held on DATE and on DATE .
CARDINAL . DATE and DATE the case file was examined by ORG .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the remainder of the applicant ’s action .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appealed and claimed that the decision was arbitrary . He also challenged the ORG judge .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found that ORG had violated the applicant ’s constitutional right to have his case examined without undue delay . In its finding ORG admitted that the case was complex from the legal point of view . It found no particular delays in the proceedings which should be imputed to the applicant and held that ORG had failed to proceed with the case in an effective manner as required by the relevant provisions of LAW . The decision stated , in particular , that there had been shortcomings in the judge ’s work which had caused excessive delays in the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE the appellate court adjourned the case as the applicant had challenged its judges dealing with the case . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request for exclusion of the judges .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG upheld ORG finding that the applicant was not entitled to compensation for the proposal in question as it was neither genuine nor did it resolve the technical problem in question as required by the relevant law . ORG further discontinued the proceedings as regards the applicant ’s claim that his proposal should be given priority as it was outside the courts’ jurisdiction . Finally , ORG upheld ORG decision on the expert ’s fees and decided that ORG judge involved was not biased . ORG judgment was served on the applicant on CARDINAL DATE .
